prefix: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would. What day of the week will it be 40 days from Tuesday?
solution: When you divide 40 days in a week by 7 days, you get a remainder of 5.  Five days from Tuesday is $\boxed{\text{Sunday}}$.
gpt_response:
To determine the day of the week that is 40 days from Tuesday, one would first recognize that the days of the week form a cycle of 7 consecutive days. Therefore, we can simplify the problem by finding the remainder when 40 is divided by 7.

40 divided by 7 gives a quotient of 5 with a remainder of 5. This indicates that 40 days from Tuesday will be 5 days beyond the next Tuesday in the cycle. Since Tuesday is the second day of the week, moving 5 days beyond it would result in Sunday.

Therefore, 40 days from Tuesday will fall on a Sunday.
solution_prompt:
The following is a response to a question. Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following response \text{Sunday?: To determine the day of the week that is 40 days from Tuesday, one would first recognize that the days of the week form a cycle of 7 consecutive days. Therefore, we can simplify the problem by finding the remainder when 40 is divided by 7.

40 divided by 7 gives a quotient of 5 with a remainder of 5. This indicates that 40 days from Tuesday will be 5 days beyond the next Tuesday in the cycle. Since Tuesday is the second day of the week, moving 5 days beyond it would result in Sunday.

Therefore, 40 days from Tuesday will fall on a Sunday.
